title: Temporary employment - bivariate relationships
text: Sara wants to examine if job permanency affects job satisfaction. She thinks that non-permanent (temporary) employees might have lower levels of job satisfaction because they feel less secure. She has identified relevant variables and is keen to explore the data.

title: Temporary employment - bivariate relationships
text: Sara wants to examine if job permanency affects job satisfaction. She thinks that non-permanent (temporary) employees might have lower levels of job satisfaction because they feel less secure. She has identified relevant variables and is keen to explore the data.

title: Temporary employment - bivariate relationships
text:
What techniques?

Sarah works on her research questions and starts to think about the techniques can she use. For each of the research questions below, select an appropriate method of exploring the relationship.


a. Is there any gender difference in permanent employment?
b. Is job permanency related to usual hours worked (i.e. are those in non-permanent jobs likely to work more hours)?
c. Do those with a permanent job report higher levels of job satisfaction?


Permanency
Here is some information about the variables to help you consider level of measurement.



Job satisfaction



Hours worked

title: Temporary employment - bivariate relationships
section: Crosstabulation: gender differences in permanent employment
text:
Crosstabulation: gender differences in permanent employment
Sara is eager to look at the data. She creates the following table to examine if there are gender differences in permanent employment.


Based on this table, which of the following can she conclude?
a) 4.9% of those in ‘temporary employment with no agreed end date’ are women
b) 91.5% of females are in permanent employment
c) A and B
d) None

title: Temporary employment - bivariate relationships
section: Examining hours worked by job permanency?
text:
Examining hours worked by job permanency?
Is job permanency related to usual hours worked (i.e. are those in non-permanent jobs likely to work more hours or less hours)? For this question, Sara gets the following output.


Which of the following are correct? [more than one can be correct]
a) Those with a permanent job work more hours on average.
b) Those in non-permanent jobs work more on average.
c) Working hours vary more among those in non-permanent jobs.
d) Working hours vary more among those in permanent jobs.


Questions to think about

Why do those in permanent positions work more hours? How should this be considered in the data analysis?
Do you think these differences are statistically significant?

title: Adding more variables in a hierarchical approach
text:
Marcos has created three models in a hierarchical approach. He wants to know how employee perceptions of their work including a sense of achievement and a sense of time to get things done relates to work stress.

Model 1 is the model presented above.
Model 2 includes the same as model 1 plus dummy variables indicated sense of achievement.
Model 3 adds a further variable for the feeling of time to get things done.

title: Adding more variables in a hierarchical approach

title: Dimensions of work-related stress - correlations
text: Marcos is examining work-related stress. He does an initial search of a relevant dataset and he finds several variables relating to different aspects of work related stress. To understand the data better he wants to examine the relationships between these variables.

title: Dimensions of work-related stress - correlations
text: Marcos is examining work-related stress. He does an initial search of a relevant dataset and he finds several variables relating to different aspects of work related stress. To understand the data better he wants to examine the relationships between these variables.

title: Dimensions of work-related stress - correlations
text:
Measure of work stress
The variables each record responses to questions asking for agreement with one of the following statements:

My job requires that I work very hard.
I never seem to have enough time to get my work done.
I feel my job is secure in this workplace.
I worry a lot about my work outside working hours.

Lower score = more agreement with the statement.

title: Dimensions of work-related stress - correlations
text:
Correlations
He wants to examine the strenght of association between these variables. He looks at the correlations between them using a correlation matrix.

Identify which values are the correlation coefficients and determine:

the strongest association?
the weakest association?

This table reports the Spearman’s rank correlation coefficients, why might this be the best choice in the situation?

title: Dimensions of work-related stress
text:
Marcos is examining work-related stress. From an initial search of a datasets, he finds several relevant variables, each of which captures agreement with one of the following statements:

My job requires that I work very hard
I never seem to have enough time to get my work done
I feel my job is secure in this workplace
I worry a lot about my work outside working hours

Lower score = more agreement with the statement. 
He wants to examine how strongly related these variables are to each other. He looks at the correlations between them using a correlation matrix.

Identify which values are the correlation coefficients and determine:

the strongest association?
the weakest association?

This table reports the Spearman’s rank correlation coefficients, why might this be the best choice in the situation?

the strongest association?

title: Temporary employment
text: Sara wants to examine if job permanency affects job satisfaction. She thinks that non-permanent (temporary) employees might have lower levels of job satisfaction because they feel less secure.  She knows there is some relevant data in the Workplace Employment Relations (WERS) Employee Questionnaire. But she’s confused about the variables and what techniques to use.

But she’s confused about the variables and what techniques to use.

title: Temporary employment
section: Examining hours worked by job permanency?
text:
Examining hours worked by job permanency?
Is job permanency related to usual hours worked (i.e. are those in non-permanent jobs likely to work more hours or less hours)? For this question, Sara gets the following output.


Which of the following are correct? [more than one can be correct]
a) Those with a permanent job work more hours on average.
b) Those in non-permanent jobs work more on average.
c) Working hours vary more among those in non-permanent jobs.
d) Working hours vary more among those in permanent jobs.


Questions to think about

How can she examine the relationship between permanency and satisfaction?
Why do those in permanent positions work more hours? How should this be considered in the data analysis?
Do you think these differences are statistically significant?

title: About
text:
About this site

title: Trade unions and maternity benefits - crosstabulation and chi-square test
text:
Ahmed is interested in examining the impact of trade unions. Specifically, he wants to investigate the following question:

Do workplaces with trade unions offer better maternity benefits?

He has the following ideas:

Yes, they will do because trade unions negotiate for better employee benefits. A causal relationship.
Yes, there will be an association because workplaces open to trade union membership treat employees better generally. An association due to some general approach taken by employers.

Either 1 or 2 suggest we should find some association.

title: Trade unions and maternity benefits - crosstabulation and chi-square test
text:

Either 1 or 2 suggest we should find some association.

title: Trade unions and maternity benefits - crosstabulation and chi-square test
text:
Crosstabulation
Ahemed examines a crosstabulation with:

Employees members of a trade union (yes/no) in the columns
Maternity pay=full pay (yes/no) in the rows


Column percentages
Ahmed creates the table using column percentages.


What percentage of workplaces with trade union members does maternity pay equal full pay?
What percentage of workplaces with no trade union members does maternity pay equal to full pay?
What percentage of all work places does maternity pay equal to full pay?



Row percentages
Ahmed creates the table with row percentages.


What percentage of workplaces have trade unions and are trade unions more or less common in workplaces where maternity pay equals full pay?
Why do the row and column percentages differ here?

title: Trade unions and maternity benefits - crosstabulation and chi-square test
text:
Chi-square test
Ahmed examines a chi-square test. What does he conclude?

title: Temporary employment - summarising variables
text:
Sara has decided to examine job permanency. She is interested in how job permanency affects job satisfaction. She thinks that non-permanent employees might have lower levels of job satisfaction because they feel less secure and are under more pressure to show their value. She also thinks that they are likely to work more hours because they feel less secure.
She knows there is some relevant data in the Workplace Employment Relations (WERS) Employee Questionnaire. But she’s confused about the variables and what techniques to use.

title: Dissertation help!
text:
Use your knowledge to help these fellow dissertation students with their data analysis!
These are a collection of (fictitious) examples of simple quantitative data analysis. Each example includes questions to answer. They are designed to support learning on BMAN60261 Workplace Research and Analysis.
Answers to the questions will be made available.

Sara 1: Temporary employment - summarising variables
Sara 2: Temporary employment - bivariate relationships
Ahmed 1: Trade unions and maternity benefits - crosstabulation and chi-square test
Marcos 1: Dimensions of work-related stress reviews - a correlation matrix
Marcos 2: Using regression to examine work-related stress
Marcos 3: Adding more variables in a hierarchical approach

title: Using regression to examine work-related stress
text: Marcos is examining work related stress. He wants to use regression analysis to examine factors associated with higher levels of work-related stress. He theorises that more hours working increases the chance of work-related stress.

title: Using regression to examine work-related stress
text: Marcos is examining work related stress. He wants to use regression analysis to examine factors associated with higher levels of work-related stress. He theorises that more hours working increases the chance of work-related stress.

title: Using regression to examine work-related stress
text:
A simple linear regression model
He starts with a simple model examining how frequency of feeling worried about work relates to the number of hours worked.

Which is the dependent and independent variable?
According to the information, does Model 1 suggests that working hours accounts for

a) 15 % of the variance in feeling worried
b) 22% of the variance in feeling worried
c) 2.2% of the variance in feeling worried




The F ratio implies the model is significant. Is this true or false?
The model predicts that a 1 unit increase in working hours results in a -0.012 decrease in scores for worry over job (Note: lower scores indicate more worry.) Is the coefficient statistically significant?
Overall, which of the following statements do the results support?

a) On average an increase in working hours is associated with lower scores on the feeling worried variable (therefore feel more worried) but the association is not statistically significant.
b) Working hours explains 22% of the variation in job stress.
c) There is a statistically significant effect of working hours on job stress but working hours does not account for much of the variation in job stress.


6. Summarise the results in one sentence.

title: Using regression to examine work-related stress
section: Building a model: Gender, working hours and being a supervisor
text:
Building a model: Gender, working hours and being a supervisor
Now, Marcos builds a multiple regression model to examine factors associated with work stress. He keeps ‘feeling worried’ as the the dependent (outcome) variable and has the following independent variables:

years working at the workplace (associated with less worry as people)
a dummy variable for males (which he predicts associated with less worry, as women more likely to report feeling worried)
being a supervisor (which he predicted is associated with more worry)

1. From the table of coefficients, which of the following are true.

a. From this model, women indicate feeling more worried than men given years in the workplace and being a supervisor.
b. On average, supervisors report a score on the worry scale of -0.36 less than non-supervisors (which indicates they are more worried, as lower scores equal more worried).
c. The model is significant
d. Tenure is associated with less worry as Marcos predicted.
e. A and B
f. C and D













B
Std. Error
Beta
t
Sig.


Model 1
